block.p: Jordanian Firm Accedes To Hostage-Takers in Iraq A Jordanian company said it would comply with the demands of the kidnappers of two of its employees in Iraq and stop its operations there. At least a dozen people have been kidnapped in Iraq since the Philippines completed withdrawing its 51 troops to spare the life of a truck driver who had been taken hostage.

Congressional committees investigating allegations of corruption and mismanagement in the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq are at odds with the organization's inquiry over access to records and personnel, legislators and officials said.

Muhammad Mamdouh Qutb, an Egyptian diplomat who was taken hostage on Thursday for four days and then released, offered a glimpse in an interview into what it was like for a hostage to be held captive by Iraq's insurgency.

Prisoners Returned to France Four French citizens held without trial for more than two years at the American prison camp at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, arrived in France and were immediately detained by French authorities.

Palestinian Leaders Reconcile The Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and his prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, publicly settled their political dispute with a pledge to pursue limited reforms that have been tried previously without success. Mr. Qurei announced he had withdrawn the resignation he submitted 10 days earlier.

China's Growing Pains Urbanization is helping to lift hundreds of millions of rural Chinese out of poverty. But, as a result, expanding megacities are spawning development schemes that escape the control of the central government.

Kerry Calls for Extension Of the 9/11 Commission Senator John Kerry called for an 18-month extension of the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, sharpening his critique of President Bush's response to its report.

The Democratic Party, in the second day of its national convention, offered up Mr. Kerry as a worthy heir to the patriots of the past, able to unite a nation divided by the administration's policies and politics.
Low Ratings for Convention Nielsen ratings suggested that total viewership of the Democratic convention on the broadcast networks may be falling to the lowest point of modern political conventions.

Florida Voting Records Lost Almost all the electronic records from the first widespread use of touch-screen voting in Florida's Miami-Dade County have been lost, stoking concerns that the machines are unreliable.

Arrests Link Charity to Terror Five former leaders of the Holy Land Foundation, once the biggest Islamic charity in the United States, were arrested on charges they funneled $12.4 million to Palestinian terrorists.
California's Budget Battle Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and California's lawmakers reached an agreement on a $103 billion budget, ending a 26-day impasse.

Medicare to Offer New Services The Bush administration announced plans to pay for initial comprehensive physical examinations, and that Medicare would cover screening tests for cholesterol and diabetes.

Fourth Newark Officer Is Shot in Wave of Violence A detective was shot in the hand as Newark police officials lined up a supply of bulletproof vests in response to a rash of violence in which three other officers have been shot.
Chef Barred From Kitchen A state judge barred Rocco DiSpirito from Rocco's on 22nd, the setting of a reality show, at the request of his feuding partners.
Rich Man, Poor Country Mayor Bloomberg touched down in Haiti for a whirlwind tour through poverty and civil unrest.
Girl's Body Is Found A body believed to be that of Brittney Gregory, a New Jersey 16-year-old missing for two weeks, was found.
Emission Deal Expected The Bush administration plans to announce an agreement with seven countries to slow global warming by capturing emissions of methane.
Food Executives Indicted Prosecutors indicted four executives of U.S. Foodservice on charges of inflating the company's earnings by more than $800 million.

US Airways Plans Overhaul US Airways plans an overhaul of the way it flies, concentrating on direct flights to and from big airports on the East Coast and dismantling its Pittsburgh hub, executives said.

Honda Study Points to Bias A study conducted by a prominent researcher found that black customers are almost twice as likely as whites to be charged a marked-up rate when they finance through Honda's loan subsidiary.
